newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - April 1.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - April 1.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the South African press on Tuesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Former defence force chiefs Jannie Geldenhuys and Kat Liebenberg and former security branch agent Craig Williamson are seeking assurances from the government that they will be protected from extradition and criminal charges in neighbouring countries if they agree to divulge details of the apartheid war.

- South Africa's trade balance swung back into the red in February, recording a 451.6 million rand deficit compared with January's 517.2 million rand surplus after seven consecutive months of surpluses, following decreases in imports and exports.
- Representatives of Zaire's warring parties are expected to meet in South Africa by the end of the week.
- Nineteen Gauteng health institutions with names that evoked bitter memories, or were associated with the past, would acquire new offical names today, the provincial health department said.

- The Reserve Bank and commercial banks have met twice in the past month to iron out details of the new foreign currency accounts proposed in last month's budget, but no decisions have yet been taken, banking sources said.
- Finance Minister Trevor Manuel has cracked the whip over billions of rand the government rolls over every year with new rules that come into effect today.
- Avis Holdings, the diversified car rental group, will list on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (JSE) next Monday at an opening price of 4,70 rand a share.

- Nando's Group Holdings, the Portuguese chicken restaurant chain, will raise 25 million rand when it lists on the JSE in the beverages, hotels and leisure sector on April 25, capitalising its local operations at 192 million rand, Robbie Brozin, the group's chairman and chief executive said.
- Consumer inflation has edged closer to the 10 percent level, from 9.8 percent in February and 9.4 percent in January, statistics show.
- Share prices worldwide will most probably come under pressure after they plunged for the second consecutive time on Wall Street.
- Trade between South Africa and India is expected to grow in the next three years to over $2 million.
- The Constitutional Court publicly warned that its time should not be wasted with unworthy applications.
